comms_internal: Same verb as 2, different pattern.
Same verb as 1, different pattern.
Alternative: salʼə̑nə̑ with either TR or NOM_INS pattern: "Petʼa iz-en salʼ-i-z" [PN.NOM stone-INS throw-PST-3SG] ‘Petja threw a stone.’

comms: The NP in the genitive displays some properties of a clause-level dependent. Alternative, less frequent pattern: DAT_NOM.
comms_internal: The DAT_NOM pattern with okmə̑nə̑: "Petʼa-lə̑ okm-e końdon-ez" PN-DAT be.enough-PRS.3SG money.NOM-3SG.POSS. The same two patterns are possible.

Same as 73. This construction with a dedicated verb for 'resemble' is probably less frequent than the one with a non-verbal predicate kadʼ 'like' (Petʼa Miša kadʼ tə̑s-ə̑n - buj-ə̑n [PN.NOM PN.NOM like face.features-INS face.features-INS]), but its advantage is that it has a less specified meaning. Apart from this, it is possible to use a construction with relational adjectives where both participants have equal rank ("Petʼa-jen Miša-jen odig tə̑s-jem-eś" [PN-INS PN-INS one face.features-PROP-PL.ADJ]).

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: There is no native verb for 'influence / affect', and the Russian borrowing влиять is perceived as not entrenched. An idiomatic way of conveying this idea would be Pereśmisa jə̑r suraśkə̑nə̑ kučʼke ńi 'When getting old (get.old:CVB), the head starts to get messed up'.
Same verb as in 68, 121, different pattern.
Synonymous verb: šuə̑nə̑, same pattern.

comms: I only have data from one consultant about this verb; it does not appear in the corpus.

comms_internal: The primary meaning of this verb is 'pull'.

comms: The terminative case, instead of the lative, is compatible with this verb as well. However, the lative is much more frequent with it. The terminative may be preferable under certain circumstances, e.g., in the phrase "reach the end" or when expressing the meaning "go / continue all the way down to Y".

comms_internal: Synonymous verb: kučʼkə̑nə̑. In the option chosen here, Y is followed by a postposition "dore" (with a free variant dorə̑). However, it is the LAT form of the relational noun dor 'vicinity', and the choice between a bare LAT and dore is partially determined by the topology and position of Y. So, generally, the NOM_LAT pattern is also possible with this verb ("Petʼa ječʼk-i-z stʼena-je" [PN.NOM touch-PST-3SG wall.NOM near-LAT]).

There is no native verb that could be perceived as a full equivalent of the Russian 'дружить'. Alternatives: družitʼ karə̑nə̑ (a not entirely entrenched Russian borrowing); bečʼejaśkə̑nə̑ 'be distant relatives;  be friends (when speaking of women or children)'. All have the same pattern.
Same as 48. Both the underived verb čʼaklanə̑ and its lexicalized detransitive derivative čʼaklaśkə̑nə̑ are equally acceptable here.
CV. This Russian borrowing is entrenched and used often.
An alternative, intransitive pattern where Y is followed by śarə̑ś 'about' is deemed acceptable, but does not appear in the corpus and is probably a recent Russian calque.
CV. There is no native verb for 'depend', and the Russian зависеть might be considered a rather entrenched (albeit infrequent) borrowing.
Same as 76.
Synonymous phrase: paldur kariśkə̑nə̑ [aside do].

back_translation_en: ‘Petja is making fun of Misha / teasing Misha.’
comms_internal: CV

comms_internal: CV. This, as well as another variant, kraśitʼtiz, is an entrenched Russian borrowing.
Same verb as in 61, 65, 96, different patterns.

back_translation_en: ‘Petja is trying to catch the cat.’
‘Petja is flattering the boss (hoping to get a promotion).’

comms_internal: Same as 119.

comms: There is no native verb for ’dream (about)’, so ’think, contemplate’ was chosen as the closest equivalent.
back_translation_en: ‘Petja is thinking / dreaming about a new car.’
comms_internal: Same as 25.
This is a passive construction. The active alternative with a generic 3PL subject can be used as well: Ta-je šu-o kompas [this-ACC say-PRS.3PL compass.NOM]. Synonymous verb: ńimaśkə̑nə̑.

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: There is no native verb for 'punish'. Closest equivalents would be kwaretə̑nə̑ 'scold, verbally express one's discontent' with the TR pattern and eś karə̑nə̑  'harm somebody on purpose, e.g., as revenge' with the NOM_DAT pattern.
Alternative pattern: LAT_NOM. Example: Vedra-je vu tə̑rm-i-z [bucket-LAT water.NOM be.filled-PST-3SG].

comms: The NP in the genitive displays some properties of a clause-level dependent. Some speakers find the DAT marking  of X acceptable, but others do not.
sentence: Petʼa-len ug okm-ə̑ odig mańet końdon-ez
glosses_en: PN-GEN NEG.PRS.3 be.enough-CNG.SG one ruble.NOM money.NOM-3SG.POSS
comms_internal: Synonymous verb: NEG + tə̑rmə̑nə̑.

comms: The NP in the genitive displays some properties of a clause-level dependent.
back_translation_en: ‘Petja hates Misha.’ (Lit. ‘Petja doesn’t want to see Misha’)
back_translation_ru: ‘Петя ненавидит Мишу’. (Букв. ‘Петя не хочет видеть Мишу’)
comms_internal: CV. There is an alternative phrase adǯʼontem karə̑nə̑ with a TR pattern, literally 'do (someone) not-needed-to-be-seen': "Petʼa adǯʼontem kar-e Miša-jez." [PN.NOM not.good.to.be.seen do-PRS.3SG PN-ACC]

comms: Non-verbal predicate.
comms_internal: Historically, this is a fossilized prs.3sg form of the verb ‘to be needed’, from which, in Beserman, apart from this form, only a fused negative prs.3sg form has survived.
This construction is acceptable, but it might be more idiomatic to use one of the passive constructions here, with an INS_NOM pattern.

comms: Not included in the database because this translation is semantically inaccurate.
comms_internal: There is no native verb for ’answer’; ’tell’ is used instead.

comms: Non-verbal predicate.

comms_internal: Same verb as in 42, 61, 96, different patterns.

comms: This construction is acceptable, however, the verb for ’plow’ is typically used intransitively (there are not so many different objects you could plow, after all). The Y argument can be expressed as a spatial adjunct in LOC, if needed: Petʼa gə̑re ludə̑n, literally ’Petya is plowing in the field’.
The word zə̑n can be a noun (’smell’) but it also functions morphosyntactically as an argument-taking predicative adjective, like here.

comms_internal: Same verb as in 14, 121, different pattern.

comms: Alternative pattern with the same verb: NOM_LAT.
back_translation_en: ‘This belt goes well with my shirt.’
comms_internal: Same as 6. Alternative: "Ta pojas tupa dʼerem-a-m" [this belt.NOM match.PRS.3SG dress-LAT-1SG.POSS].
Alternative verb: analtə̑nə̑ 'leave, abandon' with a TR pattern: "Petʼa analt-i-z vorǯʼik-em kar-ze." [PN.NOM abandon-PST-3SG be.born-PTCP.PST town-ACC.3SG.POSS]
Alternative verb: pə̑tsanə̑ 'close, lock, cover', same pattern.
Same as 33.

The same verb is normally used in the transitive construction with a variety of objects, including the names of languages ("Petʼa vala francuskij kə̑l-ez" [PN.NOM understand.PRS.3SG French tongue-ACC]). However, specifically with names of languages, Y more often forms an adverbial phrase with a postposition śamen 'in a way / manner'.

back_translation_en: ‘A lightning hit the house’, lit. ‘The house got (affected) under the lightning’.
comms_internal: Alternative possibility is the construction "čʼilʼekjan də̑rja korkaje jetiz" 'During a thunderstorm, [it] hit the house', with a null subject and the verb "jetə̑nə̑" 'to hit'. Finally, the verb "jetə̑nə̑" can also be used in the NOM_LAT pattern, but not in the lightning situation, cf. "Iz kośag-e jet-i-z" [stone window-LAT hit-PST-3SG] '‘A stone hit the window.’

comms: A variety of other postpositions can appear here, including at least və̑le and probably borde. However, they all are relational nouns in the lative case.
back_translation_en: ‘The glass got stuck to the table.’

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.

comms_internal: CV

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: There is no native verb for 'govern'. An idiomatic way of saying 'Petya governs our kolkhoz' would be 'Petya is the boss in our kolkhoz'.

comms: It is impossible to replace the postposition (’top, upper part’ in the elative case) with just the elative case on ’horse’. However, it is possible with other Ys, like, e.g., ’sledge’.

comms_internal: Same verb as 92, different pattern.

comms: The TR pattern is also possible with this verb.
comms_internal: Same verb as in 91, different pattern. The transitive pattern is also possible, though: Petʼa kə̑lǯʼik-e anaj-ze [PN.NOM listen-PRS.3SG mother-ACC.3SG.POSS].

back_translation_en: ‘The honey got mixed with the milk.’

comms: The TR pattern is also possible with this verb.
comms_internal: Cf.: "Petʼa naśk-e plʼem-jos-tə̑" [PN.NOM look-PRS.3SG cloud-PL-PL.ACC].
Same verb as in 42, 61, 65, different patterns.
Alternatively, an expression ve̮ta|z adǯʼikə̑nə̑ 'be seen in one's dream' is used, with a DAT_NOM pattern: "Petʼa-lə̑ ve̮t-a-z adǯʼ-ik-e Maša" [PN-DAT dream-LOC-3SG.POSS see-DETR-PRS.3SG PN.NOM].

comms: The case with an opaque traditional label "adverbial" is very infrequent and normally means ’in accordance with Y; using X as a guidance’. This is one of the very few constructions where it marks an argument.
comms_internal: Alternative is the construction with a non-verbal predicate "soglaš (luə̑nə̑)" (an old Russian loanword) and the NOM_INS pattern: "Petʼa Maša-ja kariśk-i-z" [PN.NOM in.agreement become-PST-3SG PN-INS].
Alternative verbs: wameńńaśkə̑nə̑, kwaretə̑nə̑ (same pattern).

comms: The predicate here is ’be’; it is not overtly expressed in affirmative, default-aspect present tense.
comms_internal: Alternative is the construction with "sə̑lə̑nə̑" (to stand) and the "NOM_NOM(NO.AGR)" pattern: "Ta tabeś sə̑l-e śu mańet" [this bowl.NOM stand-PRS.3SG hundred ruble.NOM].

The dative marking seems to be reserved for animate targets, and the lative (which is unacceptable here), for inanimate ones, e.g. "Petʼa ə̑b-i-z vorta-je" [PN.NOM shoot-PST-3SG gate-LAT] "shoot at the gate". Both can appear together, e.g., in 'shoot someone in the hand'. This is a pattern common for a handful of verbs denoting physical contact. The transitive pattern is also available for this verb ("Petʼa ə̑b-i-z kwaka-jez." [PN.NOM shoot-PST-3SG bird-ACC]). However, some speakers claim that it implies that the target was shot dead.

back_translation_en: ‘Petja poured the sugar into the cup.’
comms_internal: There is a specialized verb for 'pour' (kiśtə̑nə̑), but it is only applied to larger quantities of powder or liquid poured over the edge of a large or medium-sized container. It is not used for smaller quantities added with care; a generic 'put' is used instead, as in this example. Both have the same valency pattern though. The verb piźnanə̑ 'pour' (cognate of the Udmurt pi̮źnani̮) has the same valency pattern, but is primarily applied to thin powders poured through a sift.

Synonymous verb: aldanə̑ (also used in the transitive pattern). In the case of aldanə̑, the anticausative passive construction is somewhat more idiomatic than the bare verb with the TR pattern: Petʼa-len uśton-ez alda-śk-i-z [PN.NOM-GEN key.NOM-3SG.POSS lose-DETR-PST-3SG].
The verb ǯʼokanə̑ with the same pattern is partially synonymous with this one, but is more typically applied to animate participants.

comms: Some speakers (apparently, younger ones) also accept the TR pattern with this verb.

If the object is not a subject’s body part, this verb follows a TR pattern. This is normal for causatives of intransitive verbs, which this verb is (’move (intransitive)’ + CAUS). It might be also possible with body parts; unfortunately, I did not check this in the field.

There is no native verb for ’respect’; this one can be used but it is considered Udmurt. Alternatively, the Russian borrowing "uvažatʼ karə̑nə̑" [respect.INF(rus) make] (with the same pattern) can be used.

comms_internal: Synonymous expression: jurǯʼə̑m karə̑nə̑ [disgusted do-PRS.3SG] with the same pattern.

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: Closest native equivalents would be šum potə̑nə̑ 'be happy' (NOM_DAT) and dańńaśkə̑nə̑ 'be proud' (NOM_INS).

comms: Unfortunately, I do not have reliable data for this one. In particular, I am not sure if the pattern is NOM_DAT, DAT_NOM or both (maybe with variation among the speakers). This verb contains a detransitive derivation (however, the base verb apparently does not exist); experiencers are often DAT-widespread with such verbs. On the other hand, I also have a couple of exampes that suggest NOM_DAT, and NOM_DAT is clearly the default pattern for this verb in Standard Udmurt.
No satisfactory translation has been obtained.

comms_internal: This Russian borrowing is old and fully entrenched.

comms: The NP in the genitive displays some properties of a clause-level dependent. The bound lexeme "vož" takes case and possession suffixes but only appears in a combination with a couple of light verbs (technically, as subject or direct object). It is not a normal noun with the meaning ’anger’
comms_internal: CV. Synonymous expression: vož|ze vajə̑nə̑ (the noun vož is a direct object of the light verb 'bring') with the NOM_DAT pattern: "Petʼa vož-ze vaj-e Maša-lə" [PN.NOM (anger)-ACC.3SG.POSS bring-PRS.3SG PN-DAT].
Same as 125. Synonymous verb: abdranə̑ (also 'be confused (about / because of something)', with the same pattern).
Same as 46. Alternatively, this notion can be expressed by jaranə̑ 'be liked; be good for' (DAT_NOM): Petʼa-lə̑ jara čʼaj [PN-DAT be.liked.PRS.3SG tea.NOM].

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
Not included in the database because Y is expressed in a dependent clause.
back_translation_en: ‘Petja wants to buy a new phone.’
comms_internal: Same verb as in 14, 68, different pattern.

comms: The verb for ’be angry’ can be used in this context as well (GEN_DAT); there is no clear boundary between the two.
This verb also accepts a NOM_DAT pattern. The Y marking with və̑le ’onto’ is probably a recent calque from Russian, however, the DAT marking for Y is rejected by some speakers.
comms_internal: Synonymous verbs: ǯʼožaśkə̑nə̑, ǯʼožčʼikə̑nə̑ (same patterns). There are also several structurally different expressions for 'be mad at', which include a bound predicative adjective kur, as primary or secondary predicate, and the noun jə̑r 'head', as subject or direct object. Examples: Petʼa-len jə̑r-ə̑z kur Maša-lə̑ [PN-GEN head.NOM-3SG.POSS (angry) PN-DAT]; Petʼa jə̑r-ze kur vaj-e Maša-lə̑ [PN.NOM head-ACC.3SG.POSS (angry) bring-PRS.3SG PN-DAT]. In the former, it's not clear if the word in GEN is a clause-level argument or a possessor in an NP headed by jə̑r.
Same as 118. This is the same verb as 'be surprised'.

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: One would just say 'does not like' (TR).

back_translation_en: ‘Petja became upset because of his son.’
comms_internal: CV. Synonymous verb: "ǯʼožomə̑nə̑" with the same valency pattern.
